importantDates.descriptionOfWhyDateIsRelevant: The date of the article's publication marks the announcement of Pakistan’s successful launch of its first hyperspectral satellite, a key development in national space capabilities.

importantTimeframes.descriptionOfWhyTimeFrameIsRelevant: The time frame highlights that Pakistan’s space program is rapidly advancing, with multiple satellite launches occurring in 2025, including the H1 hyperspectral satellite.

keyTakeAways: Pakistan has launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, marking a major milestone in its space program.
The H1 satellite was launched from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025.
Hyperspectral technology allows detection of subtle chemical and material changes on the ground, useful for monitoring crop health, water resources, and disaster damage.
The satellite is expected to enhance national capacities in precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management.
The launch strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC).
SUPARCO reported that two other satellites (EO-1 and KS-1) are already fully operational, showing a broader expansion of Pakistan’s space capabilities.
It may take approximately two months to calibrate the H1 satellite before full operational status is achieved.

namedEntities.name: SUPARCO
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: SUPARCO is responsible for the launch and management of Pakistan’s space missions, including the H1 hyperspectral satellite.

namedEntities.name: H1 satellite
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite enables detailed ground analysis through hyperspectral imaging, supporting applications in agriculture, disaster monitoring, and resource management.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A satellite launch facility in China
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The H1 satellite was launched from this Chinese facility, indicating international collaboration in space launch operations.

namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: China provided launch infrastructure and is a key partner in Pakistan’s space program, reflecting strategic bilateral cooperation.

namedEntities.whatIsThisEntity: A major infrastructure initiative linking Xinjiang to Gwadar Port
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: The hyperspectral satellite's ability to assess geohazards and environmental risks supports CPEC development and long-term infrastructure planning.

namedEntities.name: EO-1 and KS-1 satellites
namedEntities.whyIsThisEntityRelevantToTheArticle: Their operational status demonstrates that Pakistan’s space program is expanding beyond a single mission, indicating a growing national capability.

summaryOfNewsArticle: Pakistan has successfully launched its first hyperspectral satellite, H1, from China’s Jiuquan Satellite Launch Centre on October 19, 2025, marking a major milestone in its space program. The satellite, capable of detecting subtle ground material changes, will support key national priorities such as precision agriculture, environmental monitoring, urban planning, and disaster management. The launch strengthens Pakistan’s strategic partnership with China, particularly in the context of the China-Pakistan Economic Corridor (CPEC), where such data can aid infrastructure development and risk assessment. While full operational status of H1 is expected in about two months, two other satellites—EO-1 and KS-1—are already fully active, showcasing a growing national space capability.
title: Pakistan launches its first hyperspectral satellite
